para.paratext: Fed. R. Evid. 803(5) and O.C.G.A. § 24-8-803(5) except “recollections recorded” from the hearsay rule. These writings are defined as a “memorandum or record concerning a matter about which a witness once had knowledge but now has insufficient recollection to enable the witness to testify fully and accurately.”

The recorded recollection must be “shown to have been made or adopted by the witness when the matter was fresh in the witness' memory and to reflect that knowledge correctly.” If admitted, “the memorandum or record may be read into evidence but may not itself be received as an exhibit unless offered by an adverse party.”[1]

A memorandum will be admissible as a record of past recollection where a witness has no independent recollection of the fact stated, but knows that the memorandum was correct when made.[2] Early Georgia cases indicated that the witness must have made the memorandum[3] or knew at some time that it was correct.[4] The exception may also be used where the declarant is a reluctant witness.[5]

When a party establishes a foundation for using documents under the exception for past recollection recorded, the writing may, unlike a document offered simply to refresh the witness's memory, be read aloud to the jury by the witness. In Platt v. National General Ins.,[6] the Georgia Court of Appeals suggested that, “after laying a proper foundation for admissibility as past recollection recorded and placing the transcript or document in evidence,” the proponent of the writing may “cause it to be read to the jury from the witness stand” or show it to the jury “by passing it around the jury box under controlled conditions” or exhibit it “in open court in the form of an enlarged reproduction.”

See, e.g., Sandlin v. State, 273 Ga. 440, 542 S.E.2d 496 (2001) (holding that document was not admissible as a past recollection recorded when social worker testified that her memory was not refreshed after reviewing the document and she was unwilling to swear that the statement accurately reflected the interview as required under the rule).

See also Jerkins v. Jerkins, 300 Ga. App. 703, 686 S.E.2d 324 (2009) (attorney's testimony that he had personally prepared letter to executor, that conversation memorialized by letter had occurred no more than three days before he wrote letter, and that he believed that the conversation had taken place as described in letter, sufficiently laid foundation for admission of letter as a past recollection recorded, even though attorney could not presently remember the conversation described by the letter).

See Akins v. Georgia R.R. & Banking Co., 111 Ga. 815, 35 S.E. 671 (1900); Bridges v. Mutual Ben. Health & Acc. Ass'n, 49 Ga. App. 552, 176 S.E. 543 (1934); Elliott v. Georgia Power Co., 58 Ga. App. 151, 158, 197 S.E. 914 (1938).
See Lenney v. Finley, 118 Ga. 427, 45 S.E. 317 (1903); Harris v. State, 191 Ga. 243, 12 S.E.2d 64 (1940); Smith v. State, 235 Ga. 852, 221 S.E.2d 601 (1976).

Pierce v. State, 302 Ga. 389, 807 S.E.2d 425 (2017) (declarant stated at trial that he was the person in the video, that he made the statements, that he had knowledge of the statements, that he told the truth when he made the statements, and the things he discussed were fresh in his memory at the time).
Platt v. National General Ins. Co., 205 Ga. App. 705, 423 S.E.2d 387 (1992).
